Anthony Mackie cannot save a slapped together Marvel movie. Director Julius Onah’s Marvel superhero spy thriller Captain America: Brave New World (2025) is quite average. Anthony Mackie is actually apt for this new take on Captain America with Falcon’s wings, but his solid acting cannot save an awfully generic script. Mackie’s earnest approach held my attention and earned my respect for his touching conversations with Carl Lumbly, Sebastian Stan, Harrison Ford, and Danny Ramirez in the grounded scenes. The dramatic scenes are where Anthony Mackie gets to shine the most. Brave New World is not as bad as I thought it’d be, but it’s hardly a standout among the entire MCU. Julius Onah’s direction lacks any real style visually. I appreciate him trying to give Captain America some heart and trust in himself that he’s worthy of the shield. The action direction is decently exciting for the Red Hulk fight and when Cap is flying. These are easily the most entertaining parts of Brave New World. It is strangely not even about Captain America entirely as it’s more a direct sequel to The Incredible Hulk, but without The Hulk. Also it directly references The Eternals’ Celestial Island remnant as well as Falcon and the Winter Soldier, so it feels very disjointed and irrelevant. Who was this for? Honestly, because as someone who wanted to give Anthony Mackie’s Falcon taking up the mantle of Captain America, this movie fails him. He’s clearly trying to be cool, calm, commanding, funny, sincere, and reasonable with a compelling performance. But, he’s been thrown a tossed together Marvel movie. Writers Julius Onah, Peter Glanz, Rob Edwards, Malcolm Spellman, and Dalan Musson craft a very predictable spy narrative for Captain America to uncover. I wish this movie focused more on Falcon and Sabra’s emotional stories and character arcs rather than this mind control espionage mystery. It’s not much of a mystery considering producer Kevin Feige already spoiled that Harrison Ford’s President Ross is Red Hulk in the marketing. Why even make this movie? I would have liked to see this story just following Mackie as Captain America finding things out without his terrible new Falcon partner. Brave New World had potential to be pretty cool, but just ends up as a middle of the road Marvel movie that has clearly been hacked and slashed by the editors due to producer notes. Anthony Mackie is a pleasant surprise as Sam Wilson with his sincere side showing. He makes for a strong, yet vulnerable Captain America. Mackie gets when to be funny and when to bring some gravitas for the serious scenes. He’s obviously the standout here. Danny Ramirez is pretty obnoxious as the wise cracking Joaquin Torres the new Falcon. He gets a great emotional scene with Mackie in the end though. Carl Lumbly is really wonderful as Isaiah Bradley, especially since he feels like a father figure to Mackie’s Sam Wilson. He brings a lot of depth, gravitas, and emotional resonance to Brave New World. Sebastian Stan’s cameo as Bucky the Winter Soldier is heartfelt and amusing alike. He’s so much more mature than many of Marvel’s actors, so he’s always a welcome sight. He later really kills it as Bucky in Thunderbolts. Shira Haas is alright as Ruth Bat-Seraph, but her ex-Black Widow Sabra feels tagged on here. She clearly was supposed to be in a much larger role before the rewrites. Her fights are fun, but I wanted more out of her scenes with Mackie, if she was here at all. Like she just leaves to go to a baseball game with Isaiah at the end. Xosha Roquemore is pretty good as Secret Service agent Leila Taylor. She just seems like good trusted friends with Sam, but she should have been a romantic interest as well! What were they thinking? Giancarlo Esposito is fairly fierce and memorable as Seth Voelker’s Sidewinder. He seems interesting as a physical opponent for Sam’s Captain America. Liv Tyler gets a sweet cameo as Betty Ross, but her being here just reminded me that Mark Ruffalo really should have been cast in this too. Tim Blake Nelson is fine as Samuel Sterns, but he’s supposed to be super smart and just does a fairly basic evil scheme. He’s clearly not the real threat once we see Red Hulk and Sidewinder. His after credits scene is bad and did not get me excited for Doomsday or Secret Wars. Harrison Ford is excellent as the furious and forlorn President Thaddeus “Thunderbolt” Ross, who is also Red Hulk. Ford gives Ross some needed humanity and empathy. I found him quite compelling. Takehiro Hira sadly only gets a bit part as Japan’s prime minister Ozaki. Editors Matthew Schmidt and Madeleine Gavin jump around all over the place with frantic cuts that ruin some of the action and make the dialogue heavy scenes feel confusing. Cinematographer Kramer Morgenthau shoots Brave New World like a television episode with not very cinematic. The close-up shots were the only emotionally engaging ones. The action is shot so far away sometimes it was hard to see what Captain America was doing exactly in these fast flying skirmishes. The CGI sets are so awful, but the visual effects for Red Hulk look awesome at the very least. I like Captain America’s wings a lot. The stunt team provide some cool close quarters combat choreography, but it’s all been done before better in previous Captain America, Black Widow, and Shang Chi fights. Composer Laura Karpman’s movie score starts out forgettable, but has some killer themes during the Captain America versus Red Hulk fight as well as the tender music during the heartfelt conversations towards the end. Sound designers Willie D. Burton, Christopher Boyes, Coya Elliott, and Lora Hirschberg record clear voices, but far too quiet oddly. I was struggling to hear people speak even with the volume turned up very loud. Costume designer Gersha Phillips came up with a neat new red, white, and blue design for Captain America in the style of Falcon’s armor. The suits all look neatly tailored. Overall, Captain America: Brave New World is at its best when Anthony Mackie gets to be a Marvel superhero on screen. This veers off to too many side characters too often for my taste, but Mackie leads the fray with a surprisingly emotionally honest performance, steadfast leadership, and some hard hitting action moves.

Going into Captain America: Brave New World, I genuinely hoped for something more impactful—especially considering the weight the title carries and the expectations set by the trailer. What we got, though, was a film that’s neither terrible nor particularly great—just somewhere in the middle, floating in the murky waters of missed opportunity. It's not so terrible that it's not watchable at all, but it's also not very good, and the end leaves you feeling like you haven't bend told the entire story the way it was supposed to be said. The biggest issue, for me, is the pacing and structure. The plot feels disjointed, almost as if it’s rushing through key moments without letting them breathe. Watching it felt like someone hit the 1.5x speed button; scenes jump from one to the next without proper build-up or payoff. It’s as if a crucial 30-45 minutes of connective tissue were cut from the final edit—scenes that would have helped everything make more sense and resonate emotionally. There are glimpses of something bigger, something more meaningful, but those moments are never fully realized. The movie feels like it should be a major installment in the MCU—especially from the scale promised in the trailer—but in reality, it lands somewhere closer to a mediocre episode of a Marvel show than a cinematic milestone. In the end, Brave New World isn't a disaster, but it also doesn’t live up to the legacy it's meant to continue. It had the pieces to be something truly memorable, but they never quite come together in a satisfying way. Overall, to put it simply: "The movie is barely worth a watch", but it's not entirely broken.

The Brave, The New, The Messy Captain America: Brave New World had all the potential to soar — but somewhere between reshoots, script rewrites, and character redesigns, it stumbled through turbulence. It still looks good (thank you, Marvel budget), but under the hood? It’s basically Civil War 2: No One Believes My Super Friend Again. Let’s be real — Sam Wilson is an amazing Captain America. His suit? Clean. His presence? Powerful. But his character arc? Kind of left hanging in the wind while Ross got the spotlight (Marvel, why you out here doing Red Hulk PR in the trailers like it's a birthday surprise we didn't ask for?). The action’s solid, the vibes are decent, but the heart doesn’t hit as hard as it should. I was torn between a 2.5 and 3, but Sam’s representation matters. So yeah — 3/5. A good movie that could’ve been a great one if it got out of its own way.

After so many rumors about reshoots, problems behind the scenes and terrible reactions at test screenings, my expectations for this film were quite neutral, which probably contributed to my reaction to it actually being more positive than I thought it would, even with its notable flaws. Sam Wilson (Anthony Mackie) really convinced me of his merit as the new Captain America, not copying the mannerisms of Steve Rogers and, at the same time, honoring the essence of the shield, both during the fights and the dialogues. I'm happy that the writers didn't simply copy his arc from the series 'Falcon and the Winter Soldier' (2021), even if they weren't very creative. Mackie's performance is great, but nothing particularly new. The highlight goes to President Thunderbolt Ross (Harrison Ford). Ford adds so many complex layers to this character, turning what was a somewhat generic villain into the coprotagonist of this story. About the supporting characters: Joaquin Torres (Danny Ramirez) as the new Falcon plays basically the same role as Sam himself in 'Captain America: The Winter Soldier' (2014) — more on these similarities later — while Isaiah Bradley (Carl Lumbly) serves mostly as a plot device to motivate the heroes. This trio (Sam, Joaquin, and Isaiah), though has little screentime, has also great chemistry. The same can't be said about Sabra (Shira Haas), a character that wasn't favored by the script (which took away everything that made her special in the comics and turned her into a carbon copy of Black Widow), nor by her actress, who delivers a very poor portrayal. When it comes to the script, I must say, it isn't very inventive. If you've watched 'Captain America: The Winter Soldier' prior, you may have noticed that this new film is, in many aspects, a worsened version of it — which is probably more than a frustrating coincidence. Never the less, it's a functional script that has its nice moments and successfully incorporates many elements of movies from the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) that for years hadn't their consequences addressed, such as 'Eternals' (2021) and 'The Incredible Hulk' (2008), working as a spiritual successor of that last one (just with no Hulk...). Anyways, the atmosphere of espionage and of political intrigues still works fairly well. About the antagonists... well, The Leader (Tim Blake Nelson) is the great criminal mind behind all of this, and I kind of liked the way they handled his character, even though, as the movie progresses, his menace slowly becomes less threatening (the fact they ignored his mental powers works in favor of that feeling). On the other hand, the SERPENT Society, led by — had to look up his name — Seth Voelker (Giancarlo Esposito) has a terribly wasted potential and is completely forgettable. Once again, the spotlights are pointed to President Ross, who dazzles all the way through, specially at the end as Red Hulk, even though he is defeated too quickly. As for the technical production, this movie has good settings and great digital effects, with the exception of some brief scenes, a refreshing news considering the questionable quality of some of the CGI from the most recent products of Marvel Studios. The action sequences, in general, are just as excellent — notably, the last one is the best of them all (what a fight!). With all of that said, 'Captain America: Brave New World' is a good action film: besides not innovating and following an old formula from its studios, works well as so and integrates some important storylines for the MCU's future. It isn't particularly remarkable, but for someone looking for a nice and short adventure, it is very welcome. (3.5/5) Note: There's one post-credit scene at the end, but i found it to be kind of unnecessary as someone who already knows about the next great Marvel event coming soon.

It's ok but given the pedigree of the trilogy that followed that's a major downgrade. Everything about it is just mediocre all around honestly. First off Mackie is ok but he just doesn't have the charisma of a leading man. The other characters around him just aren't that interesting either. the New Falcon, his mentor, the forgettable villians, nothing really helps make him more interesting or have chemistry to bounce off of. Ford isn't bad and probably is the best thing here. His weakest moments are when he's just a plot expose tool and his strongest is when he's given real character to work with. The cinemtography is so basic at times. Dull medium shots galore, some of the aciton scenes are cool when they are practically done but others like the Red Hulk fight are just alright and the CGI shows quite a bit. For such an expensive film the effects don't really show honestly. None of it is terrible but none of it is that special either. Some look better than others. the opening fight was cool and probably the best scene. Another big issue is the opening is good and probably the first 15 minutes or so it's the strongest. But the moment we got to the White House it really falls off. It becomes very unfocused at times but never convuluted. There is like 3-4 plot lines going on. The 2 villians neither of which is that special at all, the international tensions with Japan, Ross & Wilsons developments, all of it just feels very scattered but to it's credit it works enough to be passable storywise. It can look like also this has 2 different films at times too style wise. To it's credit also it does fall off quite a bit at first but it finds bottom and just kind of holds steady the entire way after just humming along. For such a troubled development the end product is passable for what it's worth but that's still a major con. Skip This. Could've been worse I guess.

This is a movie that suffers from marketing and creative not being on the same page. I don't want to post spoilers, except the commercials are one big spoiler. The commercial show a climactic battle scene where it is clear who both the participants are, but the movie tries to build suspense as to what is happening to one of those characters. Nobody seems to know what's going on, but we the audience know. We saw the commercials. And it's not played as a hey audience you know what's going on and the characters don't. It's played like they're trying to build suspense and make it a mystery. A mystery that we saw in the commercials. It's hard for the movie to overcome that huge problem and become more than just a fun way to kill 90 minutes. On the good side, the interaction between Captain America and Falcon are amazing. It's a little disappointing that there's no reason why no other former Avengers come to help Captain America, I'm not saying they should have, but there should be a reason given why they don't. So I'm hopeful for another outing that's better, because the actors did a fine job, and there were some really good scenes, but overall the plot did not live up to the standard of the top third of Marvel films.

He seems a bit too peppy to pair well with Anthony Mackies bravado and swagger. Also the build up is disappointing due to the climax being spoiled in all the trailers. Other than that it's an ok addition to the M.C.U. My problem with the M.C.U. hasn't been the actors or the characters. I think Red Hulk is too much for a Captain America who doesn't have the super soldier serum yet. This movie should have been the best of the year, especially considering you're introducing Anthony Mackie as Captain America—you need to make the audience like him. For me, it's a 4/10.

If you’re expecting a high stake, heavy and grand MCU movie you’ll be disappointed. Yes this movie didn’t do as well as expected. It’s still within the solid/average/okay/good region, depending on how you feel. But the action sequences are top notch, likeable cast. A strong message about self-worth. A villain who does the right thing in the end, another villain was kind of wasted. Despite reshoots, the pacing and chopping of the movie is seamless. This is a low level MCU film, it does its job and I left feeling happy. The post credits was spooky with a subtle hint of what’s to come. And personally, we didn’t need anything spelt out, especially as Thunderbolts post credits is the heavy hitter. Sam Wilson is fantastic as Captain America. One more thing, this movie feels like some of the initially ‘not-so-well-regarded’ movies of Phase 1-4. Such as: Thor: Dark World, Iron Man 2, Antman & the Wasp, Captain America: First Avenger, Shang Chi, Eternals, Thor, Black Widow & Incredible Hulk And now some movies are getting more love, we will certainly look back at this movie in years to come and respect its smaller scale and safe vibes. It’s a perfect contrast to Thunderbolts which was a bigger movie, evidently so… as it’s a team up movie. Cant wait to watch Cap 4 on Disney+ This movie is far from perfect and deserves its B- score but it’s not a bad movie at all.
Captain America: Brave New World is a passable superhero enterprise that delivers the swell action one comes to expect in a Marvel outing.

“Suit Up” because you’re in for a truly 🆕 yet, aspiring film/story on Sam Wilson; who is in dead Captain America, and other characters we’ve come to love and appreciate. This movie was filled to the popcorn buckets with action, continued connectivity and surprises! When the old meets now. The amount of Easter Eggs makes you want to hunt and get that “Golden Egg.” As a fan who enjoys most if not all of the MCU films for what they are, the shout outs to certain characters, Earth 616 locations; Wakanda, there was so much fun throughout this story. Authenticity, Respect, Understanding & Dedication to the Sheild and title of Captain America. Sam’s appreciation to Steve is never tested but, Sam wavers the idea of taking the mantle/title is. By the end of the film, with elements of the first trilogy, Sam solidifies his place in the “new world” and the Avengers may have found their leader… ♥️ Congratulations to Anthony, Danny & the rest of the cast on creating the next chapter to this beautiful legacy. You did good 😊

Let me be clear, I like marvel movies. I enjoy watching Kevin Feige piece together a universe & bring our comics to life. This movie is burdened by stitched together reshoots, clunky dialogue, and a story that can’t seem to figure out who its own antagonist is. This is not an actor problem, this is a writer/producer problem. I’m surprised Kevin Feige even allowed this out into the public because this was a Sony level marvel movie. Very disappointed and I hope they get this corrected in the future. Some positives, adamantium finally established, we got to revisit Tiamat, the hulk was well animated, and sidewinder is kind of a badass. However, it makes you think maybe we could have spent the 180 Million it took to make this movie on something more productive.

Captain America: Brave New World is a very good movie, and I don’t understand why people didn’t like it that much. It has good action scenes, which are also very well choreographed. It features a villain that falls a bit short, but is still not that bad. The special effects are very good, and the cinematography is wonderful. It was great that they brought back the subject of the Celestial, which had been left untouched for four years. So, for me, it’s a good superhero movie — with good characters, good action scenes, good visual effects — and I highly recommend it.

Captain America: Brave New World is not one of Marvel Studios finest movies but it’s not one of it’s worst either. It’s in between both of those areas. Somewhere in this film is a good movie. There are so many plotlines going on throughout it that the story gets convoluted. A more straight forward story would have been ok here. Anthony Mackie and Harrison Ford both deliver the goods here but still can’t elevate the script. The action is not winning any awards for action of the year. In fact I left rather dissapointed that there wasn’t more creativity here in that department. Spoiler warning is the Red Hulk doesn’t show up until about the last 25 minutes of the film. I really thought we were going to see him much sooner. The Villian is also the weakest part of the film as well and that is a problem. I can now see why this movie was not doing well with test screenings and had to go back for multiple reshoots. Captain America: Brave New World gets a 2 1/2 stars out of 5 from me.

As far as MCU movies go this one is “just ok.” There are some stand out moments in this film, but these moments are maybe 10-20% of the entire movie. The other 80% unfortunately is the same recent mind numbing/overly played-out marvel writing we’re all tired of seeing. The film suffers from bad pacing, undercooked plots and twists that are so obvious and predictable that I started checking my watch to see when the movie would finish. The supporting cast is pretty lack luster/down right cringy at times, and I was disappointed that they underutilized Giancarlo Esposito heavily in this film. Anthony Macky and Harrison Ford do a commendable job, but truthfully Carl Lumbly stole the show with his excellent performance. Overall the movie isn’t the worst thing in the MCU, but it’s no where near the best. C-

I'm not going to say that I didn't like the movie, because that would be a lie. What I think could have happened is to summarize the movie as Ross and Hulk. Apart from the final scene in the cherry trees (where the CGI was extremely poor), the dynamics of action and political conflicts were interesting on screen. Sam with a much more improved combat style, showing the evolution of the character as a whole. The hand-to-hand combat scenes were well directed. I found it interesting that finally a census about seconds to have exactly the seconds said. Sam mentions they had 28 seconds to cross the field and, yes I counted, it was exactly 28 seconds for them to enter and the guards to appear. For me, Isaiah is the most wronged character, the scene where he says he doesn't remember what happened and mentions his suit. I wish Marvel could do something better for Sam, since he's the new Captain America. Perhaps exploring the villains of the chapter better, like the serpent society, would be better as few were explored. Just as Strange's leading role in Multiverse of Madness was erased when Wanda was added, Ross being Hulk erases Sam's leading role. Anthony Mackie is amazing. The film didn't lack acting, it lacked script.

(CASTELLANO) No es que sea una mala película, pero podría haber sido mucho mejor. Brave New World arranca con fuerza, presenta un nuevo escenario y pone al frente a un Capitán América sin superpoderes... y eso, aunque suena interesante, también puede desconcertar a más de uno. ¿Cómo compite un tipo sin superfuerza en un mundo lleno de dioses, mutantes y magos? Pues con carisma, voluntad y unos cuantos tropiezos en el guion. Hay ideas que funcionan y otras que quedan en el aire. El regreso de personajes como Sterns puede pillar por sorpresa si no llevas el MCU al día. La película intenta equilibrar conspiración política con acción superheroica, pero se nota falta de pulso en el ritmo, como si el montaje no terminara de decidirse entre el espectáculo y el drama. Anthony Mackie lo da todo y cumple, pero está claro que el guion no le acompaña como debería. Harrison Ford es un añadido de lujo, aunque tampoco termina de brillar como se esperaba. La acción está bien rodada, hay escenas que enganchan, pero entre tanto personaje, subtrama y diálogo explicativo, cuesta mantener la atención. No es un desastre, tampoco es un acierto. Es otro capítulo más del MCU que entretiene lo justo pero deja la sensación de oportunidad desaprovechada. Un 6/10 que sabe a poco, sobre todo para una saga que alguna vez fue sinónimo de grandeza. (ENGLISH) It’s not a bad movie, but it could’ve been so much better. Brave New World starts strong, introduces a new setting, and puts a Captain America without superpowers at the center… and while that sounds intriguing, it might throw some people off. How does a guy without enhanced strength stand a chance in a world full of gods, mutants, and sorcerers? With charisma, grit—and a few stumbles in the script. There are ideas that work and others that just float aimlessly. The return of characters like Sterns might catch you off guard if you're not up to date with the MCU. The film tries to balance political conspiracy with superhero action, but the pacing feels uneven, like the editing couldn’t quite decide between spectacle and drama. Anthony Mackie gives it his all and delivers, but it’s clear the script doesn’t support him the way it should. Harrison Ford is a great addition, but he doesn’t shine as much as expected either. The action is well shot, and there are moments that grip you, but between all the characters, subplots, and explanatory dialogue, it’s hard to stay fully engaged. It’s not a trainwreck, but it’s not a triumph either. Just another entry in the MCU that’s mildly entertaining but ultimately feels like a missed opportunity. A 6/10 that leaves you wanting more—especially from a saga that once stood for greatness.

Anthony Mackie steps confidently into the mantle of Captain America in Marvel’s latest installment, delivering a performance that feels both earned and timely. Having long stood by the Avengers as The Falcon, Mackie’s transition into the role of Cap is a natural progression that honors the legacy of Steve Rogers while forging a new path forward. The film offers the high-octane spectacle fans have come to expect—complete with explosive action sequences, unexpected twists, and a cinematic scale befitting the Marvel name. The supporting cast boasts notable appearances from Hollywood heavyweights including Harrison Ford, Giancarlo Esposito, and Tim Blake Nelson. While their performances are solid and well-executed, they serve more to bolster the narrative than steal the spotlight. All in all, the film is a thrilling, if familiar, addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe—driven by Mackie’s compelling leadership as the new symbol of hope and heroism.

Another $300 down the drain—and for what? Brave New World is less a movie and more a $30 million checklist. Forced acting? Check. Overstuffed plot? Check. Emotional connection? Not even close. The film tries so hard to say so much that it ends up saying nothing at all. Remember when Marvel made us feel something? Now it’s just noise—loud, flashy, and utterly forgettable. The heart that once grounded the Captain America franchise has been replaced with corporate formula and hollow spectacle. Sadly, the only thing brave about this movie is thinking it would actually work.

The New Captain America — But Why? Harrison Ford — legend, no complaints there. But the new Captain America... why even do this? I’d have fewer questions if Isaiah Bradley became Cap. At least he has a backstory, pain, internal conflict. But instead, they threw Sam in the suit and acted like it all makes sense. Charisma? Zero. Facial expressions? Maybe three. Leadership or presence? None. Don’t even get me started on Cap’s sidekick. They turned Falcon into a clown. He used to be a solid partner — now he’s just comic relief. And that new shield... it’s not vibranium anymore, must be magnetic. Why? Because literally everyone — from special forces to presidential guards — shoots only at the shield, which barely covers 25% of his body. The rest? Apparently protected by plot armor. Then we have these tiny women, barely 5 feet tall, casually throwing around men three times their size. Seriously? No super serum, no logic — just because. At least Natasha Romanoff had style, skill, and training. This? Feels forced. And that Ross vs Cap fight... a complete mess. Steve Rogers had the super serum, charisma, and battle experience. This new Cap? Just a suit and a shield. No weight behind him. Steve was a symbol. This new Cap feels like a costume with no soul. Everything feels glued together — like the shield itself. But you can’t hold an audience with magnets.

This 35th Marvel Studios film is a continuation of the television miniseries The Falcon and The Winter Soldier, and follows Sam Wilson, the new Captain America, who finds himself in the middle of an international incident after meeting with President Thaddeus Ross and must discover the motive behind a nefarious global plan before the true mastermind has the entire world seeing red. How the mighty have fallen! This could have been a standout entry—especially with its strong ties to The Incredible Hulk (2008)—had it been conceived as a proper Hulk/Captain America sequel. Instead, it lands as one of the MCU’s weakest efforts, failing to match the brilliance of the previous Captain America trilogy. Anthony Mackie shines as Sam Wilson, and Danny Ramirez brings fresh energy as the new Falcon, but even their charisma can’t save this mess. The script is the real villain here—clumsy, uninspired, and lacking the sharp political intrigue that defined Steve Rogers’ films. The climax fizzles, the antagonist is forgettable, and worst of all, the film needed The Hulk and he was unfortunately absent. A missed opportunity packed with potential but poorly executed.

The superhero movie, Captain America, Brave New World was over all a fantastic experience that you should give a try. It was directed by Julius Ohna and was released in theatres in 2025. The main character, Sam Wilson, is played by Anthony Maccie and the main villains, red Hulk who was played by Harrison Ford and the Brainiac who was played by Tim Blake Nelson. In Captain America, Brave New World, Sam Wilson, who used to be the Falcon, has to take the role of Captain America, a superhero, after his retirement even though he has no superpowers. Throughout the movie he has to solve the world's problems such as preventing a potential world war, caused by Harrison Ford the new president of the USA, all the while having to deal with the immense amount of pressure that being the new Captain America entails. He is going to face superpowers threats such as Brainiac and the red Hulk. In my opinion, Anthony Maccie did an amazing job as Sam Wilson, in certain instances of the movie his face is serious and stressed which conveys his character's doubts concerning his new role. His choreography in fight scenes was also quite enjoyable. Harrison Ford also did a good job, his sultry expressions despite the fact that his character was the president perfectly conveyed his want to rekindle his relationship with his daughter. The special effects in this movie were however quite disappointing. There was nothing special about these special effects, the fire in the final fight scene was unrealistic and took me out of the movie. Other than that it was overall okay. The soundtrack had the typical uplifting aspect superhero soundtracks have. A wide variety of camera angles were used such as panning shots to capture the entirety of a battlefield during a fight scene. This film's message was that you can always redeem yourself which was conveyed by the villain Red Hulk once he accepted to go into custody to rekindle his relationship with his daughter. This is pretty convincing since the Red Hulk's relationship with his daughter took up a lot of the screen time and it left a lasting impression on me. This was a great movie and despite the numerous okay reviews this is still a good movie.

Red Hulk, Green Hulk, Pink Hulk — I don’t care. I'm not a Marvel freak, but I’m a big cinephile. That’s why I watch things I normally wouldn’t give a chance, especially when a company’s IP has mostly produced cringe-worthy stuff. What sets this Marvel film apart from most others is its solid sense of seriousness — and it’s not played off as a joke. Kind of like Endgame, which I actually really liked! The well-crafted and not overly dramatic soundtrack really emphasized that serious tone. If all Marvel movies were made like this, I’d probably be a big fan by now. Our new Captain America might not be the most remarkable actor, but Harrison Ford more than made up for that with his performance. I was honestly surprised he took part in a superhero movie, and I expected a weak showing — especially since Harrison isn’t exactly into sci-fi/fantasy stuff. All in all, Captain America: Brave New World really wasn’t that bad.

OK I saw the film for one reason: Harrison Simple as that. Been a fan for over forty years. So I had no acknowledge of the characters. None whatsoever. As the film progressed when characters from the Captain America world came in I knew nothing of their backstories. Now "And Harrison Ford". Excuse me he was the ONLY name actor in the cast. An A lister and he is in most of film and the first character you see. But got an AND. This should have been done like 1989's "Batman". Michael Keaton was a name but Jack was the bigger name and he was listed first. The film took ideas from older films, one is a surprise: Destroy the White House: 1996's Independence Day Meeting with the daughter at end of film: 2017 "Blade Runner 2049" Yep Harrison again The surprise film... The mind trick to turn people into assassins: 1988's "The Naked Gun". As a person who has always loved the music/soundtracks in films. But this one is a mixed bag. The couple of bits of loud rap music were terrible. Of course, with the brief appearance of Liv Tyler as Betty where was the Aerosmith music? With my lack of Captain America knowledge but Star Wars knowledge from the beginning I thought the Falcon character design looked somewhat Boba Fett. The main villain I thought he looked like an alien. The CGI was good. Keep this in mind as my special effects experience goes back to the original release of Star Wars. Decent film. And released 2-14-25 this was the film I looked forward to the most in 2025.
